learning_objectives.objective: Define Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) and list its key components, including exploited browser behaviors like automatic cookie transmission.
Explain how CSRF exploits the trust a web application has in an authenticated user's browser, particularly with state-changing requests (e.g., POST, PUT).
Identify CSRF vulnerabilities in provided sample code snippets involving session cookies and HTTP requests.
Compare and contrast CSRF attacks with Cross-Site Scripting (XSS), highlighting how XSS can bypass CSRF protections.
Critique the effectiveness of OWASP-recommended CSRF mitigations, such as synchronizer tokens, SameSite cookies, and double-submit cookies, in different scenarios.
Design a CSRF protection implementation for a sample web application, integrating multiple mitigation strategies and justifying choices.
